name: Precise trade-offs
description: Trade-offs method (direct) is based on the comparison of alternatives which perform differently on two criteria (assuming the performances on the other criteria is fixed). The method is applied with a survey where the respondent is asked to indicate if two alternatives are indifferent. In case they are not, the respondent can indicate which alternative he/she would prefer and then change one of the values in a way that would make alternative A as good (or as bad) as alternative B.

name: Imprecise trade-offs
reference: Adapatation from https://www.cambridge.org/core/books/decisions-with-multiple-objectives/tradeoffs-under-certainty/63531BB0093A8674D12FE2A6F9FF88B4 with inclusion of imprecise trade-offs
description: It consists in the adaptation of the precise trade-offs method by allowing respondents to assign an interval to the values that would make two alternatives indifferent.

name: Precise SWING
description:
SWING weighting refers to the change of evaluation of performance on each criterion from one value to a different one (typically from the worst to the best value).
The method considers a fictitious alternative that performs the worst on all the criteria and asks the respondent to indicate which criterion he/she would prefer to improve from its worst value to its best. This swing is assigned 100 points. The respondent is then asked to indicate which criterion of the fictitious alternative would be the second most important one he/she would like to improve from its worst to its best value. He/she should also assign a swing from 0 to 100 to indicate how important that change would be. The process continues until all the criteria are rank ordered in terms of their attractiveness on the 0-100 swing. The assigned points to each criterion are then summed up and used to normalize each criterion on a 0-100 scale.

name: Imprecise SWING
reference: Adapatation from https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0749597884710879 with inclusion of imprecise SWING
description: It consists in the adaptation of the original SWING method (see respective description) by allowing respondents to assign an interval for the points allocated to each swing in the performances of the criteria.

name: Precise points allocation
description: Respondents distribute a pre-allocated set of points (e.g., 100) to define the importance of each criterion.

name: Imprecise points allocation
reference: Adaptation from https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0749597897926947 with inclusion of imprecise points
description: It consists in the adaptation of the deterministic points allocation method by allowing respondents to assign an interval for the points allocated to define the importance of each criterion.

name: Precise direct rating
description: In direct rating, people rate each criterion on a fixed scale (e.g. 0-100 or 0-10). Minor variants include first giving the most important criterion a value of 100, or first giving the least important criterion a value of 10, the latter without having an upper bound.

name: Imprecise direct rating
reference: Adaptation from https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0305048301000445 with inclusion of imprecise rating
description: It consists in the adaptation of the precise direct rating method by allowing respondents to assign an interval for the points allocated to define the importance of each criterion.

name: Ranking
description: Criteria are ranked from most to least important. The weights are derived afterwards usually by using one of the following methods: rank sum, rank reciprocal, or rank exponent.

name: AHP
description: Criteria are compared on a pairwise comparison basis with a pre-defined semantic scale (the original is 1-9). The higher the importance of a criterion with respect to the other, the higher is the score. After these comparisons are completed, a matrix is derived based on this set of comparisons (K x K, where K is defined as the set of criteria).  The value of the weights is then derived based on the eigenvector of the matrix. The value of the weights is then derived based on the eigenvector of the matrix. The respondent is also provided with a measure of the inconsistency in the given pairwise comparisons.

name: SIMOS / Revised SIMOS / SRF
description:
The method intends to elicit the relative importance of a set of criteria from a decision maker (DM) (one person or the agreement of multiple persons).
The DM is asked to place by decreasing order of importance a deck of cards, each card representing one criterion. Ties are allowed for criteria judged to be equally important. The DM can also place blank cards between other cards in the ranking to indicate a greater difference in importance. Finally, the DM should indicate how many times the most important the first criterion (or group of criteria) is, relatively to the last ranked criterion (or group of criteria).

name: Disaggregation methods (Compensation rates)
description:
The method intends to elicit the relative importance of a set of criteria from a decision maker (DM) (one person or the agreement of multiple persons). 
The DM is asked to provide their judgment about a relatively small number of examples, each one represented by a vector of impact indicator values. The judgment can consist in choice (which vector is preferred), ranking, or classification in predefined categories. Using mathematical programming, the disaggregation approach infers a weighting vector that respects the judgment provided as closely as possible. This disaggregation strategy leads to weights whose meaning is the one of compensation rates.

name: Disaggregation methods (Importance coefficients)
description:
The method intends to elicit the relative importance of a set of criteria from a decision maker (DM) (one person or the agreement of multiple persons).
The DM is asked to provide their judgment about a relatively small number of examples, each one represented by a vector of impact indicator values. The judgment can consist in choice (which vector is preferred), ranking, or classification in predefined categories. Using mathematical programming, the disaggregation approach infers a weighting vector that respects the judgment provided as closely as possible. The disaggregation strategy leads to weights whose meaning is the one of importance coefficients.

name: SMAA (Compensation rates, no stakeholder preferences)
description: Impacts are weighted based on random sampling from a space of weight vectors, usually assuming a uniform distribution (but other distributions can be used). The space of weight vectors is the unit simplex (vectors of positive weights that add up to 100%). The meaning of the weights is the one of compensation rates. Several statistical conclusions about the results of interest can be computed (e.g., probability of winning in a comparative study).

name: SMAA (Compensation rates, with stakeholder preferences)
reference: Adaptation from https://doi.org/10.1287/opre.49.3.444.11220 with inclusion of stakeholders' preferences
description: Impacts are weighted based on random sampling from a space of weight vectors, usually assuming a uniform distribution (but other distributions can be used). The space of weight vectors is constrained by the preferences of decision makers, experts or other stakeholders. The meaning of the weights is the one of compensation rates. Several statistical conclusions about the results of interest can be computed (e.g., probability of winning in a comparative study).

name: SMAA (Importance coefficients, no stakeholder preferences)
description: Impacts are weighted based on random sampling from a space of weight vectors, usually assuming a uniform distribution (but other distributions can be used). The space of weight vectors is the unit simplex (vectors of positive weights that add up to 100%). The meaning of the weights is the one of importance coefficients. Several statistical conclusions about the results of interest can be computed (e.g., probability of winning in a comparative study).

name: SMAA (Importance coefficients, with stakeholder preferences)
reference: Adaptation from https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S1364815217308393 with inclusion of stakeholders' preferences
description: Impacts are weighted based on random sampling from a space of weight vectors, usually assuming a uniform distribution (but other distributions can be used). The space of weight vectors is constrained by the preferences of decision makers, experts or other stakeholders. The meaning of the weights is the one of importance coefficients. Several statistical conclusions about the results of interest can be computed (e.g., probability of winning in a comparative study).

name: Budget contraint
description:
A monetary valuation method where the marginal value of a Quality-Adjusted Life Year is identified on the basis of the
potential economic production per capita per year. It builds on Ecoindicator 99 values and its AoP indicators, DALY, PDF, and MJ resource depletion.

name: Abatement cost
description: Cost for control of emissions or replacements to reach certain  targets. Often, maximum marginal abatement costs (MAC)  are used or marginal abatement costs.

name: Market Price
description:
A monetary valuation method where the marginal value of a good is identified on the basis of its market price (Pizzol et al.2015)
Market price methods determine monetary values of change in the environment and not the absolute value of the environment.

name: Contingent valuation
description: Through Contingent valuation, values non-marketed goods (marketed or not) are valued inby surveys. In these surveys, hypothetical markets for the respective environmental good are created. Then the participants are asked how much they would be willing to pay for an increase of the availability of an environmental quality (WTP) or how much they would have to be compensated for to accept a certain decline in an environmental quality (WTA). The contingent valuation method (CVM) is a stated preference method. A group of respondents are asked hypothetical questions directly about their values for the environmental good. Contingent valuation includes a description of the resource or policy context, a description of the policy or proposed change in resource allocation that will be valued, a payment vehicle, and a payment rule.

name: Conjoint analysis
description: Conjoint analysis values the utility of individual attributes of maketed and non-marketed goods by surveys. In these surveys, hypothetical markets for the respective attributes of a good  are created. Several options with a combination of different conditions of the attributes are provided multiple times in surveys. Then the participants are asked which option with a set of the attributes is the most preferable, and their utility of each attribute is quantified by statistical analysis. Conjoint analysis is a stated preference method. A group of respondents are asked hypothetical questions implicitly about their utilities for the attributes of the environment (i.e. the AoPs).

name: Averting behaviour
description:
Taken from Dickie (2017), with some changes: 
Methods based on averting behavior (or avoidance, defensive, mitigating, or protective behavior) take as their main premise the notion that individuals and households can insulate themselves from a non-market bad by selecting more costly types of behavior. These behaviors might be more costly in terms of the time requirements they imply, or of the restrictions they impose on what the individual would otherwise wish to do. Alternatively, individuals might be able to avoid exposure to non-market bads via the purchase of a market good. These financial outlays are known as defensive expenditures. The value of each of these purchases represents an implicit price for the non-market good or bad in question.
Note that ISO 14008 distinguishes three kinds of averting cost methods. Here only the one is described whose costs accrue due to individual averting behavior while methods relying on costs decided by public bodies are treated under “abatement costs”.  Further note that according to ISO 14008, these costs may be used for monetary valuation only after a spending or a commitment to spending will have been made.

name: Travel cost
description: Travel Cost Methods are used to estimate recreation demand and value recreational uses of the environment such as fishing, rock climbing, hunting, boating, etc. Different cost components exist: cost of the journey to the destination in question including costs related to transport, lodging, food, entertainment, time spent and entrance fees, if any

name: Hedonic Pricing
description: Taken from Taylor (2017) and ISO 14008: Heterogeneous or differentiated goods are products whose characteristics vary in such a way that there are distinct product varieties even though the product is sold in one market (e.g., cars, computers, houses). The variation in product variety gives rise to variations in product prices within each market. The hedonic method relies on market transactions for these differentiated goods to determine the implied value or implicit price of characteristics. The hedonic pricing method uses statistical methods to isolate the implicit “price” of each of these characteristics. The most common application of hedonic theory in environmental valuation involves housing markets. The choice of housing location and, therefore, neighborhood amenities (such as scenic views, less air or noise pollution), is observable. The method can also be applied to labor markets in particular with respect to risks of death.

name: CRITIC
description: CRITIC stands for “Criteria Importance Through Intercriteria Correlation”. The method considers the standard deviation of each normalized criterion (contrast intensity) and the linear correlation between them (conflict).

name: Data envelopment Analysis
description: Data Envelopment Analysis (DEA) is a mathematical programming approach to assess the relative efficiency of a number of systems being compared. The efficiency score (eco-efficiency, or other) involves weighting multiple indicators. Each system under evaluation is allowed to choose the weighting vector that makes it compare in the best possible way against its peers. This is done by optimizing the efficiency score for each system under assessment with the weights as variables to be set. The system is deemed to be efficient if no other systems perform better given the chosen weights vector. DEA when used in the context of composite indicator construction is named “‘Benefit-of-the-Doubt’ approach.

name: Entropy
description: The method relies on the information theory to measure the amount of useful information that can be obtained. When the evaluated alternatives have a great difference between each other on a particular impact category indicator, the entropy is smaller, meaning that the impact category indicator provides more effective information, and therefore, the weight value corresponding to that indicator should be larger. On the contrary, when the differences are smaller, the entropy is larger, which shows that the amount of information provided by the indicator is smaller, and therefore, its weight value should be correspondingly smaller.

name: Factor Analysis
description:
Factor analysis (FA) is a multivariate analysis method similar to principal components analysis (PCA). It has been widely used to reduce the dimensionality of the data by identifying unknown latent variables to explain the original data.  Contrary to the PCA, which is based simply on the linear combination of the data, FA assumes that the data is based on the underlying factors of the model, and that the data variance can be decomposed into the variance accounted for by common and unique factors. Each factor is defined as a set of coefficients (so-called loadings), each measuring the correlation between the individual impact category indicators and the latent factor. Furthermore, FA is often used when there is interest in studying relations among the variables, while PCA is used when there is a greater emphasis on data reduction and less on interpretation.
The weights allocated to each impact category indicator are determined according to the proportion of its variance that is explained by the factor it is associated to. The largest factor loadings are allocated to the impact category indicators with the largest variation across the dataset, whereas smaller factor loadings are allocated to the impact category indicators with less variation across the dataset.

name: Principal Component Analysis
description: The method consists of transforming the decision matrix into a series of equations (as many as the number of indicators), representing linear transformation of the original data, in such a way that the maximum variance of the original impact category indicators is explained with the first equation, the second-highest variance (which is not explained by the first equation) is explained by the second equation, and so on. The linear combinations of the original indicators are called principal components. The factor loading of the first principal components are rotated to minimize the number of individual variables that have a high loading on the same component. These factors are generally considered the indicators weights. Furthermore, the largest factor loadings are assigned to the indicators with the largest variation across the dataset, whereas smaller factor loadings are assigned to the indicators with less variation across the dataset.

name: Regression analysis
description:
Regression analysis is a statistical method to assess the relationship between a set of independent variables (indicators) and a dependent variable (an outcome measure) based on observation data.
For example, Karl Pearson’s correlation ratio (also known as the first order sensitivity index) is calculated with respect to the composite indicator, i.e., the index obtained from the aggregation of the individual indicators. This correlation ratio is a coefficient of nonlinear association and can be considered as ex post measure of importance.

name: Carrying capacity
description: Carrying capacity estimates from the literature matching existing LCIA midpoint impact indicators are used to develop weighting factors.

name: Planetary boundaries
description: Planetary boundaries estimates from the literature (mainly: Rockstrom et al. 2009; Steffen et al.) are used to develop weighting factors to applicable impact categories at midpoint or, potentially, endpoint.

name: EDIP97
description:
EDIP methodology is focused on the use of LCA for product development. It is a generic and full-fledged methodology. 
There are 2 versions of the EDIP method: EDIP97 and EDIP2003. Later servers as a follow-up, not an update, but a spatially differentiated alternative. Only EDIP97 has a weighting of environmental impacts included.
The basis for weighting in EDIP 97 is political environmental targets within each impact category (set as a reduction in society´s impact on the environment) and considers only binding targets. The original set of weighting factors was defined for Denmark. Weighting is performed only at midpoint level (EDIP methodology only has indicators at this level).

name: Swiss Eco-Scarcity
reference: Frischknecht R., Büsser Knöpfel S. 2013: Ökofaktoren Schweiz 2013 gemäss der Methode der ökologischen Knappheit. Methodische Grundlagen und Anwendung auf die Schweiz. Bundesamt für Umwelt, Bern. Umwelt-Wissen Nr. 1330: 256 S.: https://www.aramis.admin.ch/Default?DocumentID=61250&Load=true
description: Environmental exchanges are evaluated in relation to political targets for Switzerland (and lately extended to other geography, e.g. the EU).
